title: 108_hr4025
content: The Act titled "Child Health Care Affordability Act" introduces a new section 25C in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a credit for medical expenses for dependents. The "Child Health Care Affordability Act" introduces a new section 25C in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing a tax credit for medical expenses for dependents. The credit can be up to $500 per dependent, with an increased limit of $3,000 for dependents with terminal diseases, cancer, disabilities, or other health conditions requiring specialized care. The new section 25C in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a tax credit for medical expenses for dependents, up to $500 per dependent, with a higher limit of $3,000 for dependents with specific health conditions. The aggregate credits allowed to a taxpayer can be increased under certain conditions, coordinating with nonrefundable credits. The new section 25C in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a tax credit for medical expenses for dependents, up to $500 per dependent, with a higher limit of $3,000 for dependents with specific health conditions. The credit allowed under this subpart reduces the amount of credit otherwise allowable without regard to section 26(a). Definitions for terms like medical care, dependent, disability, and social security taxes are provided. Expenses allowed as a credit under section 21 are excluded from being treated as expenses paid for medical care under this section. The $500 and $3,000 limits for tax credits on medical expenses for dependents will be adjusted for inflation in taxable years after 2003. Increases will be based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. Any increase not a multiple of $10 will be rounded up to the next highest multiple of $10. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for claiming the credit on Form 1040EZ. Subsection (e) of section 213 is amended to deny double benefits for medical expenses deduction. Conforming amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart A. The amendments made by this section apply to medical expenses for dependents. Effective Date: The changes apply to amounts paid after the enactment date in taxable years ending after that date.
